awd_titl_txt: International Travel Support during 2016-17 for U.S.-Japan Research Collaboration on the Seismic Design and Testing of Mid-Rise Reinforced Concrete Buildings
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support a group of U.S. researchers to travel to Japan during 2016 and 2017 to continue a research collaboration with Japanese colleagues to develop and conduct a seismic testing program for two full-scale, ten-story reinforced concrete building models on the three-dimensional, full-scale earthquake testing shake table facility (E-Defense) operated by Japan's National Research Institute for Earth Science and Disaster Resilience.  The first building model was tested during November and December 2015, and the second building model is planned to be tested during May 2017.  By working with Japanese colleagues, the U.S. researchers will contribute to the design, instrumentation, and testing protocols of the building structures, and will gain access to the test data for use in subsequent research analyses.  Subsequent studies using the data generated in these tests can help advance simulation methods for improving the seismic resilience of buildings and communities in the United States.  The U.S. participants will be selected based on their expertise, as well as to promote participation from underrepresented groups. This award is part of the National Earthquake Hazards Reduction Program.  

Under NSF award CMMI-1547833, U.S. researchers participated in the seismic testing of the first ten-story building model on the E-Defense shake table during November and December 2015. The first building model had moment-resisting frames in one direction and shear walls in the orthogonal direction.  The base of the structure was constructed first to study the effects of simple sliding devices on building response and then locked to create a fixed-based condition to enable testing to severe damage.  The focus of this award is on the seismic design and testing of the second ten-story building model, which will be conceptually similar to the first structure, but with different design details. The second structure will be designed to have many features in common with U.S. reinforced concrete buildings, including moment frames and rectangular shear walls designed to withstand effects associated with the inelastic response of buildings subjected to strong earthquakes that drive the buildings to near collapse.  For these second tests, the U.S. participants will aim to gather data that can serve as the basis for future research within the U.S., including research on computational models to simulate the response of buildings to strong earthquake shaking.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, THE

por.por_cntn:
This project continued a long-standing international collaboration between researchers in Japan and the United States conducting research on earthquake-resistant reinforced concrete building structures. Over several decades of research collaboration, the participants have shared data on how to improve earthquake resistance of buildings, thereby accelerating the development of knowledge and practices for improved seismic performance. 

In this project, researchers from the United States participated in the planning, execution, and interpretation of a series of shaking table experiments on two full-scale reinforced concrete building structures tested on the E-Defense shaking table in Japan. Funding enabled the United States researchers to travel to Japan to participate in planning workshops, to witness and assist in testing, and to discuss the principal findings and lessons from the research. 

By participating in the program, the researchers from the United States were able to gain access to a unique and highly valued data set on the dynamic response of full-scale reinforced building structures subjected to earthquake ground motions near the collapse state. As part of the program, researchers from the United States were able to deploy their own instrumentation on the shaking table test structures, thereby enhancing the data available to researchers from Japan and the United States.

The collected data are being used for two primary purposes. First, the physical tests were a proof test of current design and construction methods and served to identify weakness in current building code requirements that will affect development of future building codes. Second, the measured dynamic responses are enabling researchers in the United States and Japan to calibrate numerical/computer methods for simulating building responses to strong earthquakes. The computer simulation methods enable us to extend the immediate findings from these individual tests to better understand building responses to earthquake shaking in a more general context. They are also being widely used in the private sector to improve building designs in seismically active parts of the United States. 

The collaboration also contributed to intellectual development of the next generation of young researchers from the United States and Japan who participated in this international collaboration. 

Digital video recordings of the tests are widely used to enhance university instruction of engineering students. 

The results of the international collaboration are being collected into a series of technical publications that will be published in a dedicated issue of the Bulletin for Earthquake Engineering.


Last Modified: 07/08/2022
Modified by: Jack P Moehle
